items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

Extract and generalize the assert_gem and assert_no_gem methods from the internal SharedGeneratorTests module. Also introduce supplementary assert_gems and assert_no_gems helpers.

The assert_gems method asserts that the Gemfile includes an entry matching each of the provided gems:

assert_gems "rails", "propshaft"

In addition to gem names, it accepts a Hash mapping gem names to constraints:

assert_gems rails: "~> 8.0.0"
assert_gems rails: ["> 6.1", "<=8.0.0"]
assert_gems rails: {github: "rails/rails", branch: "main"}

Both style can be combined in a single call:

assert_gems "propshaft", rails: "~> 8.0.0"

The assert_no_gems method asserts that the Gemfile does not include any entries for the provided gem names.

assert_no_gems "sprockets", "sprockets-rails"

items.content_html:
Ensure ActiveSupport::BroadcastLogger only executes blocks once.

Motivation / Background

Fixes #49745 #52876
Related #51883 #49771

Prior to this change, BroadcastLoggers would iterate each broadcast and execute the user provided block for each. This resulted in unintended behaviour since a user-provided block could execute multiple times.

The consumer of any Logger would reasonably expect than when calling a method with a block, that block would only execute a single time. That is, the fact that a Logger is a BroadcastLogger should be irrelevant to consumer.

The most significant example of this is with ActiveSupport::TaggedLogging. If a BroadcastLogger is used, and there are multiple loggers being broadcast to that respond to the tagged method, then calling tagged with a block would result in the block being called multiple times. For example:

broadcasts = ActiveSupport::BroadcastLogger.new(
  *Array.new(2) { ActiveSupport::TaggedLogging.logger }
)
number = 0
broadcasts.tagged("FOO") { broadcasts.log(++number.to_s) }
 # Outputs:
 # [FOO] 1
 # [FOO] 1
 # [FOO] 2
 # [FOO] 2

The same issue also applies when calling info, warn, etc. with a block.

Detail

This commit modifies the implementation used for dispatching to instead 'wrap' the block calls such that the user-provided block is only executed in the innermost call. (An assumption is made that when passed a block, all loggers will yield it, and have the same return semantics.) For example, the above example would effectively be executed as so:

broadcasts[0].tagged("FOO") {
  broadcasts[1].tagged("FOO") {
    yield
  }
}
items.title: Fix ActiveSupport::BroadcastLogger from executing a block argument for each logger (tagged, info, etc.)

Motivation / Background

This is a change in the code generated by the authentication generators. It aims to avoid exposing the password reset token in the URL to not give access to 3rd party scripts or off-domain images, avoiding leaking data to a referer.

Most users using the authentication generators will probably be unaware of the consequence of putting the password reset token in the URL. This can lead them to accidentally expose it in tracking URLs or images. To prevent this, we can limit the exposure to the password reset token as much as possible by putting the password reset token in the session.

items.content_html:
Fixes #53082.

Motivation / Background

This Pull Request has been created because running bin/rails generate authentication does not add the bcrypt gem if there is no # gem "bcrypt" comment in the Gemfile, and this prevents authentication from working.

This is because the authentication template does bundle add bcrypt --quiet, but --quiet is not a valid option for bundle add.

Detail

This Pull Request changes the authentication template to use plain bundle add bcrypt with Thor's capture: true option.

Additional information

I chose that solution because it was the quickest fix to still hide output in the spirit of what was originally intended, while keeping the style of the original code. But a side effect is that if bundle add fails for any reason, no error message will be shown, because stderr will also be hidden.

Alternatively we could:

  • run bundle add bcrypt without --quiet, but that would result in wordier output like this:

        bundle  add bcrypt
Fetching gem metadata from https://rubygems.org/..........
Resolving dependencies...
Fetching gem metadata from https://rubygems.org/..........
Resolving dependencies...

  • Add gem bcrypt in the Gemfile with Rails' gem helper or Thor's insert_into_file, followed by bundle install --quiet.

  • use another way to run bundle add silently, although that would change the style of the original code. Something like:

    • say_status :run, "bundle add bcrypt"; system('bundle add bcrypt', out: File::NULL)
    • or copy/pasting or requiring bundle command + exec_bundle_command from the app_base generator, although that wouldn't work out of the box because you can't pass the quiet option except globally, so you would need to copy/paste and/or tweak. Feels like too much.

I can update the PR if one of these options is preferred.

Detail

This Pull Request has been created because when rails tries to resolve the database url, it tries use the parsed url's scheme. If we're using an SQLite database, there is no URL, but there is a file path. While using the default SQLite, we get an undefined method to_sym' for nil (NoMethodError)error, since there is no.schemefor a filepath. This PR addresses this. Since the default database is SQLite, this code change sets the default adapter tosqlite3` if the URL fails to resolve.

items.content_html:
Tested this over here, but I feel pretty confident it keeps most of the desired behavior.

Auto-label PRs

  • When a Pull request is created or updated, add a label based on file paths changed
  • Labels will update if there is a change to the PR, e.g. rebase, etc
  • This is the only job (unfortunately) that will add a status check to a PR
    • We can roll it into an existing workflow to avoid that, and make it continue-on-error

Stale

  • Runs once a day
  • Ignores PRs
  • Ignore issues with "exempt" labels
  • Adds "stale" label after 90 days with a comment
  • Closes 1 week later with no comment

Unstale

  • Triggered on update to issue or issue comment
  • Skips if the actor is the bot itself (avoid loop from add label -> unstale)
  • Checks for "stale" label and removes if exists

More info needed

  • Runs daily
  • Must add "more-info-needed" label manually (unchanged current process)
  • After 2 weeks of no update,
  • Uses the "stale" action to instead close the issue immediately
    • TODO: remove "more-info-needed" label in unstale job (sorry just noticed this when opening the PR)

Sorry I hit submit before finishing the description.

Opening this now to get some feedback, but we probably want to remove / disable the old probot before merging this.

This is something I've wanted to do for a while, it gives us more control over the changes which influence the Issues team work and processes. Plus the old bot is likely running on some very outdated software, and on a physical machine someone is paying for.

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

As explained in the Mozilla documentation:

When a user reloads the browser, the browser will send conditional requests for validating to the origin server. But it's not necessary to revalidate those kinds of static resources even when a user reloads the browser, because they're never modified. immutable tells a cache that the response is immutable while it's fresh and avoids those kinds of unnecessary conditional requests to the server.

See: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Cache-Control
and https://www.keycdn.com/blog/cache-control-immutable

I believe it's an effective and straightforward approach to improve performance.

For instance, GitHub is already using it in production.

Following @dhh's PR #52883

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

TL;DR redirect_to and assert_redirect_to both currently accept non-redirect status codes

Detail

Currently, redirect_to and assert_redirected_to will gladly accept "nonsensical" status values, e.g. :bad_request. I say nonsensical because using redirect_to implies that you intend to, well, redirect! But browsers (and turbo) will not process these responses as redirects because their HTTP response status falls outside the 3XX range

Additional information

A potentially much better option would be to change ActionController::Redirecting#redirect_to to raise an error upon encountering a non-3XX. I didn't tackle that but would be happy to give it a shot.

This gotcha is mitigated to some extent by this helpful note in the docs
